commander.name: Major-General Raymond Briggs
commander.previous_service: Commander, 2nd Armoured Brigade; participated in First Battle of El Alamein

M3 Grant.note: 75mm gun in hull sponson, 37mm gun in turret

supply_logistics.supply_status: Adequate for defensive operations, being refitted after First Alamein and Alam Halfa. Division in reserve status receiving new Sherman tanks and reorganization. Primary supply route from Alexandria via coastal railway and road network (120km). Fuel and ammunition stocks recovering after summer battles.

weather_environment.terrain_type: Coastal plain transitioning to rocky desert plateau. El Alamein defensive positions.

subordinate_units.note: Main armoured component - 3 armoured regiments (The Queen's Bays, 9th Queen's Royal Lancers, 10th Royal Hussars)
Motorized infantry - 3 battalions (2nd Battalion, The Rifle Brigade; 2nd Battalion, King's Royal Rifle Corps; 7th Battalion, The Rifle Brigade)
3x Field Regiments (25-pdr), 1x Anti-Tank Regiment, 1x LAA Battery
Field squadrons for mine clearance, bridge construction, defensive works
3 squadrons providing line, wireless, and dispatch rider communications
RASC, RAMC, RAOC, REME units for supply, medical, ordnance, and maintenance

tactical_doctrine.role: Mobile armoured warfare, combined arms operations with armoured brigade and motorized infantry
tactical_innovations: Integration of new American Sherman tanks with superior firepower
Improved coordination between armour and motorized infantry
Better use of divisional artillery for armoured support
known_issues: Rebuilding after heavy losses earlier in 1942
Integrating new equipment (Shermans) with existing Crusaders
Limited operational experience as complete division - often dispersed to support other formations
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: Specialized desert navigation, water discipline, vehicle maintenance in sand conditions, dust filtration for engines

special_rules: Sherman 75mm gun superior to German Pz III/IV in some scenarios
Good logistical support from Eighth Army
Division rebuilding - not at full combat effectiveness until late September
historical_engagements: First Battle of El Alamein (July 1942) - elements only
Battle of Alam Halfa (Aug-Sep 1942) - limited role
Second Battle of El Alamein (Oct 1942) - full division participation

source: Joslen, H.F. (2003) [1960]. Orders of Battle: Second World War, 1939-1945. Naval and Military Press. ISBN 978-1-84342-474-1. Pages covering 1st Armoured Division organization and command structure 1942.

Playfair, I.S.O. et al. (2004) [1960]. The Mediterranean and Middle East: British Fortunes Reach their Lowest Ebb (September 1941 to September 1942). History of the Second World War United Kingdom Military Series, Vol. III. Naval & Military Press. ISBN 978-1-84574-067-2.

Playfair, I.S.O. et al. (2004) [1966]. The Mediterranean and Middle East: The Destruction of Axis Forces in Africa. History of the Second World War United Kingdom Military Series, Vol. IV. Naval & Military Press. ISBN 978-184574-068-9.
British Army Lists (Quarterly), July 1942 - October 1942. UK Ministry of Defence. Official government records for commander verification and unit assignments.
TM 30-410: Handbook on the British Army (1942). US War Department. Official manual covering British armoured division organization and equipment.
Battle Orders 028: Desert Rats - British 8th Army in North Africa 1941-43. Osprey Publishing. Pages covering 1st Armoured Division at El Alamein.

unithistories.com - 1st Armoured Division chronology confirming Raymond Briggs command from 19 August 1942, subordinate units (12th Lancers, 2nd RHA, 11th RHA, 76th Anti-Tank Regiment), and operational timeline through Q3 1942.
Tank inventories: 1 Grant, 92 Sherman, 68 Crusader (documented for September-October 1942 from multiple cross-referenced sources including Playfair Official History and unit establishment tables)

precise_subordinate_commanders.reason: Historical sources confirm Briggs as GOC and general brigade structure, but specific brigade commanders for Q3 1942 not fully documented in available authoritative sources
sources_checked: Playfair Official History Vol. III & IV
precise_subordinate_commanders.mitigation: Used confirmed commanders where documented in primary sources, indicated known gaps

exact_vehicle_counts_by_type.reason: Establishment tables provide total vehicles (~3000), but exact breakdown by truck model and support vehicle types requires detailed unit war diaries
exact_vehicle_counts_by_type.estimate_method: Based on standard British armoured division establishment for August 1942 (13,235 personnel, ~3,000 vehicles) from TM 30-410 and Joslen

detailed_nco_breakdown.reason: Total personnel known (13,235), officer/enlisted ratio estimated from standard British divisional establishments
detailed_nco_breakdown.estimate_method: Applied standard ratios from TM 30-410: ~7% officers, ~18% NCOs, ~75% enlisted
